{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{infobox person | name=A. F. Salahuddin Ahmed | birth_date={{birth date|1924|9|24|df=y}} | birth_place=[[Motihari]], Bihar, British India | death_date={{death date and age|2014|10|19|1924|9|24|df=y}} | death_place=[[Dhaka]], Bangladesh | alma_mater=[[University of Calcutta]]
[[University of Pennsylvania]]
[[University of London]] }} '''A. F. Salahuddin Ahmed''' (24 September 1924 – 19 October 2014) was a [[Bangladesh|Bangladeshi]] historian, humanist and rationalist thinker.{{cite news |title=National professor Salahuddin Ahmed passes away |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2014/10/19/national-professor-salahuddin-ahmed-passes-away |newspaper=bdnews24.com |date=19 October 2014 |access-date=2014-11-07}} == Early life and education == Ahmed was born in [[Motihari]], [[Bihar]]. He came from an educated [[Bengali Muslims|Bengali Muslim]] family. His father Abu Ahmed Faizul Mohi, paternal grandfather Moulvi Ahmed, one of the early Bengali Muslim high-ranking administrators in British India, and maternal grandfather [[Azizul Haque (police officer)|Azizul Haque]], (who is credited with having a major contribution to the development of [[Henry Classification System]] of [[fingerprint]] method) were all students of [[Presidency College, Calcutta]]. He received his I.A. from [[Surendranath College]], (formerly Ripon College), and B.A. (Hons.) in history from [[Presidency College, Kolkata|Presidency College]] (now Presidency University). He completed his first M.A. in history from [[Calcutta University]], and then a second M.A. in history from [[University of Pennsylvania]], and his Ph.D. in history from the [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] at [[University of London]] (1961). ==Professional career== Ahmed started his teaching career in 1948 as a lecturer at [[Jagannath College]], [[Dhaka]]. Later, he was a lecturer, reader, and then professor of history at [[Rajshahi University]]. He was also a professor of history at [[Jahangir Nagar University]] and [[Dhaka University]], the job from which he retired in 1984. In 1963, Ahmed was invited by the American Historical Association as a visiting lecturer in South Asian history at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] and the [[University of Chicago]]. He was also [[UNESCO]] Cultural Fellow at [[Kyoto University]], Japan in 1956. Ahmed was also associated with [[Independent University, Bangladesh]] as Professor of National Culture and Heritage, and served as the president of the National Association of Social Sciences of Bangladesh, and chairman of the United Nations Association of Bangladesh. ==Personal life== Ahmed was married to [[Hamida Khanom]], who was one of the very few early Muslim graduates (I.A. and B.A.) from [[Bethune College]], Calcutta. She completed her M.A. from Calcutta University, and then a second B.A. (Hons.) from [[University College London]]. She retired as Principal of [[Home Economics College, Dhaka]]. Hamida provided support and inspiration to Ahmed in his professional career throughout their long 60 years of married life. ==Publications== The following quote from the review of one of Ahmed's book: ''Perspectives on History, Society and Politics'' published by Readers Service, Kolkata, 2001, aptly captures his views and reputation {{cite web|url=http://www.vedamsbooks.com/no37124.htm |title=Perspectives on History, Society and Politics/A.F. Salahuddin Ahmed |publisher=Vedamsbooks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-12}} {{quote|"This is a compilation of articles written over last two decades by a renowned historian of Bangladesh, Professor A.F. Salahuddin Ahmed on topics relating to history, society, and politics of the Indo-Pakistan-Bangladesh subcontinent, which is now known as South Asia. The main contention of the author is this that despite political divisions which took place in 1947 the people of this vast region belong to "one indivisible civilization which is the product of over thousand years of historical development." It was due to the machinations of "certain vested interests, both indigenous and foreign" the common people had to pass through untold misery and suffering: and, these 'vested interests, even threatened their 'civilized existence. Professor Ahmed is of the opinion that the destinies of the common people inhabiting this sub-continent 'are closely interlinked'. "They must", therefore, "learn to live together in peace which is essential for their development and progress." He made sincere efforts through these articles to promote greater awareness about the problems raised and to provoke "new thoughts concerning peace and understanding among the people of the three countries."}} In 2012, Ahmed contributed a chapter, entitled "Bangladesh, Present, and Future Prospects" in a memorial book in honor of his younger deceased brother, Fakhruddin Ahmed, a career diplomat,and twice Foreign Secretary of Bangladesh, titled, ''Regional Cooperation and Globalization: Bangladesh, South Asia and Beyond edited by Dr. Zillur Rahman Khan and Dr. Meghna Guha Thakurta'',{{cite web|url=http://www.uplbooks.com/book/regional-cooperation-and-globalisation-bangladesh-south-asia-and-beyond |title=Regional Cooperation and Globalization:Bangladesh, South Asia and Beyond |publisher=uplbooks |date= |accessdate=2012-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202010509/http://www.uplbooks.com/book/regional-cooperation-and-globalisation-bangladesh-south-asia-and-beyond |archivedate=2012-12-02 }} where he makes a case for appreciating historical perspectives of social and political events: {{quote| The present state of Bangladesh has to be viewed in the light of the past because, as has been said, the present "is the child of the past and parent of the future." In order to understand the problems and predicaments which confront the country at the present moment we have to turn back to the past. Without understanding the past we cannot understand the present. If we look at history we would find that during the past hundred years or so phenomenal changes have taken place in what may be called the psyche of the Muslims who form the great majority of population of the region. These changes have to be explained and analysed in historical perspective.}} In 2004, Ahmed in collaboration with Bazlul Momin Choudhury, published a comprehensive editorial volume on the history of Bangladesh, entitled ''Bangladesh:National Culture and Heritage: An Introductory Reader'',{{cite web|url=http://www.colorsofbangladesh.com/boipatra1.php |title=Colors Of Bangladesh |publisher=Colors Of Bangladesh |date= |accessdate=2012-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220125447/http://www.colorsofbangladesh.com/boipatra1.php |archivedate=2012-02-20 }} which gives an overview of the land, society, culture and religions, and history of the peoples of Bangladesh. Some other notable books {{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/s?ie=UTF8&search-type=ss&index=books&field-author=Salahuddin%20Ahmed&page=1 |title=Salahuddin Ahmed: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-12}} in English and Bengali written by Ahmed are: * ''Social ideas and social change in Bengal 1818-18-35'' * ''Bangladesh Tradition and Transformation,Bengali Nationalism and the Emergence of Bangladesh'' * ''Itihash O oitijjo Bangalir Sadhana O Bhangalir Muktijuddha'' * ''Bangladesh Jatiyabad, Swadhinata'', Gonotantro He has also contributed many articles in professional journals. ==Social activities== Ahmed's interest and involvement in social service is reflected by his work for the [[Red Cross]] during the turbulent period of [[Partition of India]], and his association with the [[Radical Democratic Party (India)|Radical Democratic Party]]{{cite web|url=http://my.opera.com/PRC/blog/m-n-roy |title=Absurdist Republic - M. N. Roy - The Radical Humanist |publisher=My.opera.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-12}} founded by [[M.N.Roy]], and his active involvement in Ahmed Memorial Foundation established by family members dedicated to the educational and social welfare of their ancestral village of Bashbaria in Faridpur, Bangladesh. He maintained an active life until the day he died, serving as the National Professor, writing and publishing articles, giving media interviews. He maintained worldwide contacts with his students, and professional acquaintances, as well as with their children and grandchildren, as many of them continued to seek him out for advise and support, as did his own family, and his house served as intellectual, social, and family gathering place during his lifetime. ==Awards== * [[Ekushey Padak]] (1991). * Bangladesh Sadhinota Padak ([[Independence Day Award]]), (1999). * National Professor Appointed by the Government of Bangladesh, 2011 ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahmed, A.F.Salahuddin}} [[Category:Bengali historians]] [[Category:Historians of South Asia]] [[Category:Surendranath College alumni]] [[Category:Presidency University, Kolkata alumni]] [[Category:University of Calcutta alumni]] [[Category:University of Dhaka faculty]] [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:Indian Muslims]] [[Category:Recipients of the Ekushey Padak]] [[Category:Recipients of the Independence Day Award]] [[Category:National Professors of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Bengali Muslims]] [[Category:Honorary Fellows of Bangla Academy]]

revision.text: {{use dmy|date=June 2016}}{{use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox scholar | name = Anton van Hooff | image = Anton van Hooff 2.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = Van Hooff at Utrecht Freethinkers in the Pub, March 2015. | fullname = Antonius Jacobus Leonardus van Hooff | othernames = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1943|10|06|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[The Hague]] | residence = [[Nijmegen]] | workplaces = [[Radboud University Nijmegen]] | alma_mater = [[Radboud University Nijmegen]] | thesis_title = Pax romana: een studie van het Romeinse imperialisme | thesis_year = 1971 | main_interests = Classical antiquity {{Listen|embed=yes|filename=Anton van Hooff - voice - nl.ogg|title=Anton van Hooff's voice|type=speech|description=[[:File:Anton van Hooff - voice - nl.ogg|Recorded June 2015]]}} }} '''Antonius Jacobus Leonardus (Anton) van Hooff''' (born 1943) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[historian]] of [[ancient history|antiquity]], [[author]] and a former [[docent]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.trouw.nl/tr/nl/4324/Nieuws/archief/article/detail/1587009/2010/04/17/Het-onzalige-duo-Nero-en-Seneca.dhtml |title=Het onzalige duo Nero en Seneca |author=Hans Oranje |work=[[Trouw]] |date=17 April 2010 |accessdate=23 January 2015}} From 2009 until 2015, he chaired the [[freethought|freethinkers]] association [[De Vrije Gedachte]].{{Cite journal |last=van Hoof |first=Anton |date=May 2013 |title=Openingstoespraak van de voorzitter |journal=De Vrijdenker |volume=44 |issue=4 |pp=3}}{{Cite journal |last=Kruithof |first=Dik |date=May 2015 |title=Afscheid van Voorzitter Anton van Hooff op jaarvergadering De Vrije Gedachte |journal=De Vrijdenker |volume=46 |issue=4 |pp=3}} In 1971, Van Hooff graduated with the [[dissertation]] ''Pax romana: een studie van het Romeinse imperialisme'' ("Pax Romana: a Study of Roman Imperialism"). Until 2008, Van Hooff was [[docent]] in [[ancient history]] at the [[Radboud University Nijmegen]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.trouw.nl/tr/nl/5009/Archief/archief/article/detail/3351233/2012/11/21/Van-eeuwige-kroonprins-tot-modelkeizer.dhtml |title=Van eeuwige kroonprins tot modelkeizer |author=Willfred van de Poll |work=Trouw |date=21 November 2012 |accessdate=23 January 2015}} He specialises in [[classical antiquity]], and regularly publishes in various newspapers and magazines. He wrote several books, including ''Nero & Seneca'', ''Athene'' ("Athens") and ''Marcus Aurelius''. Van Hooff is an [[atheism|atheist]],{{Cite news |url=http://www.trouw.nl/tr/nl/5009/Archief/article/detail/3461945/2013/06/20/Humanisten-Softer-dan-ooit.dhtml |title=Humanisten? Softer dan ooit |author=Wilfred van de Poll |work=Trouw |date=20 June 2013 |accessdate=18 February 2017}} a [[republicanism in the Netherlands|republican]]{{Cite news |url=http://www.nrc.nl/handelsblad/van/1997/maart/13/de-republikeinse-vereniging-7345823 |title=De Republikeinse Vereniging |author=Anton van Hooff |work=NRC Handelsblad |date=13 March 1997 |accessdate=31 May 2015}} and a member of the [[Republican Society]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.montesquieu-instituut.nl/id/viq0f94ttqy7/a_j_l_anton_van_hooff |title=Dr. A.J.L. (Anton) van Hooff |work=Montesquieu Instituut |date=27 April 2013 |accessdate=12 June 2015}} On 3 December 2014, Van Hooff held the first ever Hans van den Bergh Lecture of the [[New Republican Society]] in [[De Balie]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ORlOnG61r1Y |title=1e Hans van den Bergh lezing door classicus Anton van Hooff in de Balie te Amsterdam |author=Anton van Hooff |work=[[YouTube]] |publisher=[[New Republican Society]] |date=15 December 2014 |accessdate=12 June 2015}} == Books == * ''Zelfdoding in de antieke wereld (1990)/From Autothanasia to Suicide. 1926 (Second discovery at B.N.Y.) | location = Bank of New York
(New York City) | id = }} The '''Bank of New York Hoard''' is the name given to identify a [[treasure trove]] of several thousand [[Fugio Cent]]s that were discovered at the [[Bank of New York|bank]]. Sometime in 1788, a keg of Fugio cents were acquired by the bank and stored in the basement. The coins were forgotten about until they were rediscovered in 1856, this time at the bank's current location. At that time the coins were placed in cotton bags and put away until a final rediscovery of the coins was made in 1926.{{cite web|url=http://www.coins.nd.edu/ColCoin/ColCoinIntros/Fugio.intro.html|title=The Fugio Cent of 1787: Introduction|publisher=www.coins.nd.edu|accessdate=November 18, 2016}} The coins were then given out as souvenirs and keepsakes to clients until 1948 when the [[American Numismatic Society]] examined the remaining 1,641 coins. Several of the coins were donated to the society while others were sold to collectors.{{cite book|title=A Guide Book of United States Coins|author=R.S. Yeoman and Kenneth Bressett|publisher=[[Whitman Publishing]]|year=2017|page=31}} All of the coins found were in [[Uncirculated coin|mint state]] condition, most with brown [[Toning (coin)|toning]]. The find was important to collectors who wished to obtain a mint state example of the coin.{{cite web|url=http://www.numismaster.com/ta/numis/Article.jsp?ArticleId=25556|title=More Than Morgans in Coin Hoards|author=Paul M. Green|publisher=www.numismaster.com|date=July 24, 2012|accessdate=November 19, 2016}} The bank kept 819 of the remaining coins which range in grade from mint state to corroded due to past water damage while in storage. Despite the merger which led to the bank's closure in 2007, it was reported in 2013 that the coins still remain on the property. The owners have refused to distribute the remaining coins, and have kept them for historical value and appreciation.{{cite web|url=http://www.hlrc.com/articles/09132013.pdf|title=Collecting the Coins of Famous Hoards|publisher=www.hlrc.com|author=Dave Wnuck|date=September 13, 2013|accessdate=November 19, 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Treasure}} {{Coin-stub}} [[Category:Numismatics]] [[Category:Treasure troves of the United States]] [[Category:Historical currencies of the United States]] [[Category:Bank of New York]] [[Category:History of New York City]]

{{italic title}} The '''''Basic Encyclopedia''''' is an encyclopedia of the [[United States Air Force]] that lists places that are targets for bombing. It was begun in 1946 during the [[Cold War]] as the '''''Bombing Encyclopedia''''' and included over eighty-thousand potential targets around the world during the [[Cold War]]. This included their B.E. number (which consisted of an eight digit identifier), a brief description, longitude and latitude, elevation, category (i.e. military, industrial, or an airfield).<ref name=Schlosser>{{cite book|last1=Schlosser|first1=Eric|title=Command and Control Nuclear Weapons, the Damascus Accident, and the Illusion of Safety.|date=2014|publisher=Penguin Group USA|isbn=0143125788|page=204|edition=1st|quote=They began by poring through the Air Force's ''Bombing Encyclopedia'', a compendium of more than eighty thousand potential targets located throughout the world. The book gave a brief description of each target, its longitude and latitude and elevation, its category—such as military or industrial, airfield or oil refinery—and its "B.E. number," a unique eight-digit identifier. From that lengthy inventory, twelve thousand candidates in the Soviet Union, the Eastern bloc, and China were selected.}}</ref><ref name=Gregory>{{cite news|last1=Gregory|first1=Derek|title=Bombing Encyclopedia of the World|url=http://geographicalimaginations.com/2012/08/03/bombing-encyclopedia-of-the-world/|accessdate=1 June 2015|publisher=geographical imaginations|date=3 August 2012}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{History of Bangladesh}} '''Bikrampur''' ("City of Courage") was a [[pargana]] situated {{convert|12|mi}} south of [[Dhaka]], the modern capital city of [[Bangladesh]]. In the present day it is known as [[Munshiganj District]] of Bangladesh. It is a historic region in [[Bengal]]. It was a part of the [[Bhawal Estate]].
==History==
===Early history=== [[Ashoka]], the emperor of the [[Maurya Empire|Maurya Dynasty]], ruled all of major parts of Bengal from ca. 269 BC to 232 BC.<ref>Thapur (1973), p. 51.</ref> Being a devotee of [[Gautama Buddha]], he propagated [[Buddhism]] across his kingdom which included Bikrampur to the east. Following the high ideals of this religion, [[Pala Empire|Pala Kings]] came to Bikrampur to rule the region.<ref name=romance>{{cite book|pages=26|title=The Romance of an Eastern Capital|first=F.B.|last=Bradley|publisher=Smith, Elder & CO|year=1906}}</ref>
===Pala Era=== The second ruler of [[Pala Empire]], [[Dharmapala (emperor)|Dharmapal]], built a [[Buddhist monasticism|Buddhist monastery]] in Bikrampur during his reign in 770–810.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ray |first=Krishnendu |year=2012 |chapter=Vikramashila Mahavihara |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Vikramashila_Mahavihara |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref> After his death, his son, [[Devapala (Pala dynasty)|Devapala]] ruled this area until 850 CE. Then the region is successively ruled by [[Vigrahapala I]], [[Narayanapala]], [[Rajyapala]], [[Gopala II]], [[Vigrahapala II]], [[Mahipala]], [[Naya Pala]], [[Vigrahapala III]], [[Mahipala II]], [[Shurapala II]], [[Ramapala]], [[Kumarapala (Pala king)|Kumarapala]], [[Gopala III]] and [[Madanapala (Pala dynasty)|Madanapala]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Chowdhury |first=AM |year=2012 |chapter=Pala Dynasty |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Pala_Dynasty |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref> [[Pala empire]] disintegrated in 1174 weakened by attacks of the [[Sena dynasty]].<ref name = Scott>{{cite journal | last = Scott | first = David | title = Buddhism and Islam: Past to Present Encounters and Interfaith Lessons | journal = Numen | volume = 42 | issue = 2 | pages = 141–155 | date=May 1995 | doi=10.1163/1568527952598657 |jstor = 3270172 }} </ref>
===Chandra Era=== During the rule of [[Srichandra]] (reigned 930 – 975 AD), the administrative centre of the [[Chandra dynasty|Chandra kingdom]] was established at Bikrampur.<ref>{{cite book |last=Chowdhury |first=AM |year=2012 |chapter=Chandra Dynasty, The |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Chandra_Dynasty,_The |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref>
===Sen Era=== A copper-plate inscription from the time of the ruler [[Vijay Sen]] (ruled 1097–1160), founder of Sen dynasty, was found in [[Barrackpore]], in 1911. In this inscription, Bikrampur was mentioned as the capital of that region.<ref name =companigonj.com>[http://www.munshigonj.com/MgonjSection/HistoryOldBangla.htm Proof of Bikrampur as the ancient capital of Bengal], Golam Ashraf Khan Uzzal</ref> It continued to be the capital throughout the, [[Sena Dynasty]]. In 1205, Turkic invader [[Bakhtiyar Khalji]] defeated the then-ruler [[Lakshman Sen]] in [[Nadia district|Nadia]]. Lakshman fled to Bikrampur.<ref>{{cite book |last=Misra |first=Chitta Ranjan |year=2012 |chapter=Laksmanasena |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Laksmanasena |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref> His two sons [[Vishwarup Sen]] and [[Keshab Sen]] kept ruling from here until 1230.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyfiles.co.uk/KingListsFarEast/IndiaBengal.htm|title= Far East King Lists|accessdate=30 December 2013}}{{self-published source|date=August 2016}}</ref> But the copper-plate inscriptions during their reign do not mention Bikrampur as the capital.<ref name=bpedia>{{cite book |last=Chowdhury |first=AM |year=2012 |chapter=Vikramapura |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Vikramapura |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref> Another Hindu ruler, [[Danuj Rai]], defeated a successor of Keshab Sen and started ruling from here. In early 1280 he moved the capital to Suvarnagrama (later named Sonargaon).<ref name=bpedia/><ref>{{cite book |last=Taher |first=MA |year=2012 |chapter=Raja Ganesha |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Raja_Ganesha |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref>
===Mughal Era=== Emperor [[Akbar]] established Bikrampur as one of the 52 [[pargana]]s of Sonargaon [[Sarkar (country subdivision)|sarkar]] in Bengal [[Subah (province)|subah]] during his administrative reforms in 1572–1580.<ref>Abul Fazl-I-'Allami (1949, reprint 1993). [[Ain-I-Akbari]], Vol.II (tr. H.S. Jarett), Calcutta: The Asiatic Society, p.151</ref> During his time, Chand Rai<ref>{{cite book |last=Khan |first=Muazzam Hussain |year=2012 |chapter=Chand Rai |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Chand_Rai |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref> and Kedar Rai<ref>{{cite book |last=Khan |first=Muazzam Hussain |year=2012 |chapter=Kedar Rai |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Kedar_Rai |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref> were the [[Zamindar]]s of Bikramapur. In the expeditions against [[Bara-Bhuiyans]], Mughal Subahdar [[Man Singh]] killed Kedar Rai in early 1600s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Szfqq7ruqWgC&pg=PA64 |title=Bangladesh|work=google.com|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
In post-[[Aurangzeb]] era, during the time of [[Murshid Quli Khan|Nawab Murshid Quli Khan]], Bikrampur was divided into eight [[taluk]]s – ''Bhagyakul'', ''[[Sreenagar Upazila|Sreenagar]]'', ''Maijpara'', ''Sinhapara'', ''Taltala'', ''[[Sirajdikhan Upazila|Sirajdikhan]]'', ''Louhojong'' and ''Baligaon''. Each taluk was represented by one Zamindar. Muhammad Azim Khan became the Zamindar of Louhajong who held the title of "Khan Bahadur". Gobinda Prasad Roy became the Zamindar of Maijpara.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.munshigonj.com/heritage/Maijpara.htm|title=:: Munshigonj District – Heritage Places – Maijpara Math ::|work=munshigonj.com|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{For|the trials in Upper Canada during the War of 1812|Bloody Assize of 1814}} [[Image:George Jeffreys, 1st Baron Jeffreys of Wem by William Wolfgang Claret.jpg|thumb|[[George Jeffreys, 1st Baron Jeffreys|Judge Jeffreys]]]] The '''Bloody Assizes''' were a series of [[trial (law)|trials]] started at [[Winchester]] on 25 August 1685 in the aftermath of the [[Battle of Sedgemoor]], which ended the [[Monmouth Rebellion]] in England. There were five judges – Sir William Montague ([[Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer]]),{{cite book|last=Whiles|first=John|title=Sedgemoor 1685|publisher=Picton Publishing|location=Chippenham|year=1985|edition=2nd|isbn=978-0-948251-00-9}} [[Robert Wright (judge)|Sir Robert Wright]], Sir Francis Wythens ([[Court of King's Bench (England)|Justice of the King's Bench]]), [[Creswell Levinz|Sir Creswell Levinz]] ([[Court of Common Pleas (England)|Justice of the Common Pleas]]) and [[Sir Henry Pollexfen]], led by [[Lord Chief Justice of England|Lord Chief Justice]] [[George Jeffreys, 1st Baron Jeffreys|George Jeffreys]]. [[File:Bloody assizes.jpg|thumb|right|A 19th-century artist's impression of Judge Jeffreys presiding over the "Bloody Assizes".]] Over 1,000 rebels were in prison awaiting the trials, which started in Winchester on 26 August. The first notable trial was that of an elderly [[gentlewoman]] named Dame [[Alice Lyle]]. The jury reluctantly found her guilty, and, the law recognising no distinction between principals and accessories in [[treason]], she was sentenced to be [[Death by burning|burned]]. This was commuted to [[decapitation|beheading]], with the sentence being carried out in Winchester market-place on 2 September 1685. From Winchester the court proceeded through the [[West Country]] to [[Salisbury]], [[Dorchester, Dorset|Dorchester]] and on to [[Taunton]], before finishing up at [[Wells, Somerset|Wells]] on 23 September. More than 1,400 prisoners were dealt with and although most were sentenced to death, fewer than 300 were hanged or [[hanged, drawn and quartered]].{{cite web |url=http://www.britainexpress.com/History/battles/sedgemoor.htm |title=The battle of Sedgemoor |accessdate=21 November 2007 |work=Britain Express }}{{cite web |url=http://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/ASH/Bloodyassize.htm | title=The Bloody Assize|publisher=Somerset County Council|accessdate=21 October 2012}} The Taunton Assize took place in the Great Hall of [[Taunton Castle]] (now the home of the [[Museum of Somerset]]). Of more than 500 prisoners brought before the court on the 18/19 September, 144 were hanged and their remains displayed around the county to ensure people understood the fate of those who rebelled against the king.{{cite web |url=http://www.everythingexmoor.org.uk/_T/Taunton_Castle.php |title=Taunton Castle |accessdate=21 November 2007 |format= |work=Everything Exmoor }} Some 800–850 men were [[penal transportation|transported]] to the [[West Indies]]{{cite web |url=http://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/ASH/Bloodyassize.htm |title=The Bloody Assize |accessdate=17 December 2015 |work=Somerset County Council }} where they were worth more alive than dead as a source of cheap labour{{cite web |url=http://www.earlymodernweb.org.uk/emn/index.php/archives/2004/11/from-the-dnb-the-bloody-judge/ |title=George Jeffreys (1645–1689) |accessdate=20 February 2008 |format= |work=Early Modern Notes }} (the novel ''[[Captain Blood (novel)|Captain Blood]]'', and the later movies based on it, graphically portray this punishment). Others were imprisoned to await further trial, although many did not live long enough, succumbing to 'Gaol Fever' ([[typhus]]), which was rife in the unsanitary conditions common to most English [[Jail|gaols]] at that time. A woman named [[Elizabeth Gaunt]] had the gruesome distinction of being the last woman burnt alive in England for political crimes.{{cite web |url=http://www.strum.co.uk/twilight/shepton5.htm |title=The Bloody Assizes |accessdate=20 February 2008 |work=From Watford Gap to Camelot }} Jeffreys returned to London after the Assizes to report to [[James II of England|King James]], who rewarded him by making him [[Lord Chancellor]] (at the age of only 40), 'For the many eminent and faithful services to the Crown'. Jeffreys became known as "the [[hanging judge]]". After the [[Glorious Revolution]], Jeffreys was incarcerated in the [[Tower of London]], where he died in 1689. His death was probably due to his chronic medical history of kidney and [[bladder stone]]s leading to an acute infection, [[kidney failure]] and possibly [[Bacteremia|toxaemia]]. Writing as recently as 1929, Sir John C. FoxFox was Vice-Chairman of Oxfordshire Quarter Sessions and had been Senior Chancery Master of the Supreme Court. said:
Even to the present day, the mothers of West Somerset control their unruly offspring by threatening to send for 'Judge Jeffreys'.Sir John Fox, ''The Lady Ivie's Trial'', (Oxford University Press, 1929), xlix.

[[Harvard University]] }} '''Dirk Anthony Ballendorf''' (April 22, 1939 – February 4, 2013) was an American-born Guamanian [[historian]] and [[professor]] of [[Micronesia]]n studies. Ballendorf, a specialist on Micronesian [[culture]], [[politics]], [[current events|current affairs]], and history, authored more than two hundred articles and eleven books during his career.{{cite news |first=Joy |last=White |title=Micronesia historian Ballendorf dies at 73 |url=http://www.mvariety.com/cnmi/cnmi-news/local/53345-micronesia-historian-ballendorf-dies-at-73 |work=[[Marianas Variety]] |publisher= |date=2013-02-06 |accessdate=2013-02-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LhSUQlTy?url=http://www.mvariety.com/cnmi/cnmi-news/local/53345-micronesia-historian-ballendorf-dies-at-73 |archivedate=2013-12-08 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news |first= |last= |title=UOG's Dr. Dirk Ballendorf dies |url=http://www.kuam.com/story/20952744/2013/02/03/uogs-dr-dirk-ballendorf-dies |work=[[KUAM (disambiguation)|KUAM]] |publisher= |date=2013-02-03 |accessdate=2013-02-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LhShp37f?url=http://www.kuam.com/story/20952744/2013/02/03/uogs-dr-dirk-ballendorf-dies |archivedate=2013-12-08 |deadurl=no |df= }} He taught in the Department of Micronesian Studies at the [[University of Guam]] for more than thirty years. ==Biography== Ballendorf was born on April 22, 1939, in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]].{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Funeral for the Late Dr. Dirk Ballendorf Set for Monday |url=http://www.pacificnewscenter.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=31309:video-funeral-for-the-late-dr-dirk-ballendorf-set-for-monday&catid=45:guam-news&Itemid=156 |work= [[Pacific News Center]] |publisher= |date=2013-02-07 |accessdate=2013-02-17}} He earned a [[bachelor's degree]] at West Chester State College, presently [[West Chester University of Pennsylvania|West Chester University]] Ballenforf joined the [[Peace Corps]] after college and attended [[Ateneo de Manila University]] while serving in the [[Philippines]]. He next completed a [[master's degree]] in [[history]] from [[Howard University]] in Washington D.C. and a doctorate in planning and administration from [[Harvard University]] in Massachusetts. In 1977, Ballendorf became the president of the [[College of Micronesia-FSM|College of Micronesia]] on [[Pohnpei]] in the present-day [[Federated States of Micronesia]]. He served as president until 1979, when he joined the faculty of the [[University of Guam]] as director of the Micronesian Area Research Center. Ballendorf served as director of the Micronesian Area Research Center from 1979 to 1984 and again from 2004 until 2007. Ballendorf authored eleven books and more than two hundred articles on the history of Micronesia. One of his best known works was ''The Secret Guam Study'', a book which documents the [[political status]] of [[Guam]].{{cite news |first=Samuel F. |last=MacPhetres |title=The Secret Guam Study Boom Review |url=http://marshall.csu.edu.au/MJHSS/Issue2005/MJHSS2005_108.pdf |work= [[Micronesian Journal of the Humanities and Social Sciences]] |publisher= |date=June 2004 |accessdate=2013-02-17}} Ballendorf co-authored the book with a [[Washington D.C.]] [[lawyer]] [[Howard P. Willens]], who had served as the legal counselor for the [[Marianas Political Status Commission]] beginning 1972 through the completion of the negotiations which created the [[Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands]] in 1978. To obtain the classified documents needed for the book, Ballendorf filed requests under the [[Freedom of Information Act]] in November 2000.{{cite news |first=|last=|title=The Secret Guam Study|url=http://www.guampdn.com/guampublishing/special-sections/university_mag/secret-guam.htm |work= [[University of Guam Magazine]] |publisher= |date=2013-02-06 |accessdate=2013-02-17}} When the requests were denied, Ballendorf and Willens filed suit against the [[U.S. Department of State]], the [[U.S. Department of the Interior]], and the [[U.S. Department of Defense]], all of which soon provided the requested documents. Ballendorf and Willens used the documents to write their book, which was published in 2004. Ballendorf died in his sleep on the morning of February 4, 2013, at the age of 74. He was survived by his wife, Francesca "Paka" Remengesau, who was from [[Palau]]; daughter, Heidi, the marketing administrator for the Guam Waterworks Authority, and son, Hans. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://nmhcdigitalarchive.org/OralHistory1/Ballendorf,%20Dirk%20A.pdf Interview of Dirk A. Wilson |year=2001 |isbn=0-8242-0970-2}}{{cite book|title=Harmonization and standardization of Nigerian languages |first1=Francis O. |last1=Egbokhare |first2=S. Oluwole |last2=Oyetade |page=106 |publisher=CASAS |year=2002 |isbn=1-919799-70-2}} is the capital of [[Enugu State]] in [[Nigeria]]. It is located in southeastern Nigeria. The city had a population of 722,664 according to the 2006 Nigerian census. The name ''Enugu'' is derived from the two [[Igbo language|Igbo]] words ''Énú Ụ́gwụ́'' meaning "hill top" denoting the city's hilly geography. The city was named after [[Ngwo|Enugwu Ngwo]], under which coal was found. Since the 17th century the location of present-day Enugu has been inhabited by the Nike ({{IPAc-en|n|iː|ˈ|k|eɪ}} {{respell|nee|KAY|'}}) subgroup of the [[Igbo people]]; one of Enugu's neighbourhoods still retains the village's old name [[Ogui]]. In 1900 the [[Southern Nigeria Protectorate]] was established by the colonial administration of the [[British Empire]]. The discovery of coal by the colonialists led to the building of the Eastern Line railway to carry coal from the inland city to the port of [[Port Harcourt]], a city created for this purpose located {{convert|151|mi|km}} south{{cite book|title=The Nigeria handbook |author=Nigeria, Chief Secretary's Office |edition=10 |page=83 |location=Eastern Line |publisher=Government Printer, Lagos|year=1933}} of what was called Enugu Coal Camp. Enugu was then renamed simply ''Enugu'' and developed as one of the few cities in West Africa created from European contact. By 1958 Enugu had over 8,000 coal miners. {{As of|2005}} there are no significant coal mining activities left in the city. Enugu became the capital of the [[Eastern Region, Nigeria|Eastern Region]] after Nigeria's independence in 1960; a succession of territorial adjustments in 1967, 1976 and 1991 led to Enugu becoming the capital of what is now Enugu State. On 30 May 1967 Enugu was declared the capital of the short-lived [[Republic of Biafra]]; for this Enugu is known as the "capital of [[Igboland]]." After Enugu was captured by the Nigerian armed forces, the Biafran capital was moved to [[Umuahia]]. Industries in the city include the urban market and [[Bottling line|bottling]] industries. Enugu is also one of the filming locations for directors of the [[Cinema of Nigeria|Nigerian movie industry]], dubbed "Nollywood". Enugu's main airport is the [[Akanu Ibiam International Airport]]. The main educational establishment in the city is the Enugu campus of the [[University of Nigeria, Nsukka|University of Nigeria]] based in [[Nsukka]], a town north of Enugu and in the same state. ==History== ===Early history=== The first settlement in the Enugu area was the small Nike village of Ogui, which was present since the era of the [[Atlantic Slave Trade]].Udo, p. 88. ''Nike'' in the Igbo language means "with strength or power."Williams, p. 196. It was through [[slave raiding]] that the Nike people acquired most of their lands, which were mostly unsettled. The Nike used slaves for a defence strategy, placing slave camps at the edge of their territories so that it was harder for an enemy to access the free born.Udo, p. 92. The Nike people were allied to the [[Aro people]] who formed the [[Aro Confederacy]] (1690—1901){{cite journal|title=The Evolution of the Aro Confederacy in Southeastern Nigeria, 1690–1720: A Theoretical Synthesis of State Formation Process in Africa |first=Apollos |last=Nwauwa |journal=Anthropos |issue=4–6 |publisher=Anthropos Institute |year=1995 |volume=90 |pages=353–364 |issn=0257-9774}} which was an Igbo organisation that controlled slave trading in the Enugu area.{{cite journal |journal=Africa |volume=24 |issue=4 |title=The Ohu System of Slavery in a Northern Ibo Village Group |first=W.R.G. |last=Horton |year=1954 |pages=311–336 |publisher=Edinburgh University Press | doi = 10.2307/1156711 }} Along with the Aro people who came to trade from [[Arochukwu]] in the south were the [[Hausa people]] who came to trade from the north. The Hausa traders provided horses to the Nike which were used for rituals by the Igbo. Both the Aro and Hausa migrated back and forth to what is now the city of Enugu and were considered foreigners to the area.{{cite journal|title=Explaining Inter-Ethnic Coexistence and Harmony in Enugu city, Southeastern Nigeria |first=Akachi Cornelius |last=Odoemene |publisher=University of Ibadan |pages=6–8 |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:1alpOUdSuSAJ:iussp2009.princeton.edu/download.aspx%3FsubmissionId%3D90623+Explaining+Inter-Ethnic+Coexistence+and+Harmony+in+Enugu+city,+Southeastern+Nigeria&hl=en&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgfS7i6J5YxEHceZG9ZdYv4g-HjZ0RCwIB9FM-Vpduh8FvNUlYWg1i3wI35yKyQMX7UIMcLfOqdeP4VfHoq4mAbwHgRo-R3cI2sVQ_QQOggYXkYwXEExnHv_mizVboLDEc03SFo&sig=AHIEtbTZa9w6FJWeoGADzwaG2fxd2m4y9g}} ===Industrialisation=== {{See also|Colonial Nigeria}} [[File:Iva Valley coal mine.jpg|thumb|alt=A picture of the Iva Valley coal mine from 2006.|The Iva Valley coal mine]] A British campaign to invade Arochukwu and open up the hinterland for British military and political rule was carried out in 1901. A war between the British and Aro officially started on 1 December 1901 lasting till 24 March 1902 when the Aro were defeated.{{cite book|title=Missionary enterprise and rivalry in Igboland, 1857–1914 |first=Felix K. |last=Ekechi |pages=123–125 |publisher=Routledge |year=1972 |isbn=0-7146-2778-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WNwgU_0wQukC&pg=PA123}} The Aro Confederacy ended and the rest of Aro dominated areas was added to The Colony and Protectorate of Southern Nigeria, declared in 1900.{{cite book|title=The school in the service of evangelization: the Catholic educational impact in eastern Nigeria, 1886–1950 |first=Nicholas Ibeawuchi |last=Omenka |pages=112–115 |publisher=BRILL, 1989 |isbn=90-04-08632-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qYQEUH--BO0C&pg=PA112|year=1989 }}{{cite book|title=Oil, democracy, and the promise of true federalism in Nigeria |first1=Augustine A. |last1=Ikein |first2=Diepreye S. P. |last2=Alamieyeseigha |first3=Steve S. |last3=Azaiki |page=353 |publisher=University Press of America |year=2008 |isbn=0-7618-3928-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qzL0-nBbMCQC&pg=PA353}} Europeans first arrived in the Enugu area in 1903 when the British/Australian [[geologist]] [[Albert Ernest Kitson]] led an exploration of the [[Southern Nigeria Protectorate]] to search for especially valued mineral resources under the supervision of the [[Commonwealth Institute|Imperial Institute, London]]. By 1909 coal was found under the village of Enugwu Ngwo in the Udi and Okoga areas and by 1913 the coal was confirmed to be in quantities that would be viable commercially. By 1914 the colonial government had already merged the [[Northern Nigeria Protectorate|Northern]] and Southern Nigeria Protectorate to form the [[Colony and Protectorate of Nigeria]].{{cite book|title=Nigeria, background to nationalism |first=James S. |last=Coleman |page=43 |publisher=University of California Press |year=1971 |isbn=0-520-02070-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2MTI-Y3tzkAC&pg=PA43}} In 1915 the British began talks with the indigenous people of the land that would become Enugu about its acquisition in order to lay the Eastern Line railway and to build a colliery. The first houses built in the area were in a temporary settlement consisting of Igbo traditional mud housing inhabited by a W.J. Leck and some other Europeans on Milliken Hill. Another settlement known as ''Ugwu Alfred'' (Igbo: Alfred's Hill) or "Alfred's Camp", inhabited by an Alfred Inoma (a leader of indigenous labourers from [[Onitsha]]) and his labourers, was located on a hillside.{{cite book|title=Management of environmental problems and hazards in Nigeria |first=H. Chike |last=Mba |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd |page=291 |year=2004 |isbn=0-7546-1394-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UBtILsKGKIcC&pg=PA291}} After the land acquisition by the British, [[Frederick Lugard]], the [[List of Governors-General of Nigeria|Governor-General of Nigeria]] at the time, named the colliery built at the bottom of the Udi Hills ''Enugu Coal Camp'' to distinguish it from Enugwu Ngwo which overlooks the city from atop a scarp on Enugu's west.{{cite book|title=Eastern Nigeria: a geographical review |first=Barry |last=Floyd |page=282 |publisher=Praeger |year=1969}} The first coal mine in the Enugu area was the Udi mine opened in 1915 which was shut down two years later and replaced with the Iva Valley mine.Udo, pp. 196–197.Sklar, pp. 207–210. Enugu became a major coal mining area and the only significant one in West Africa. The Eastern Line railway connecting Enugu with [[Port Harcourt]] was completed in 1916 in order to export the coal through its seaport of which the city was created for this purpose.Williams, p. 200. Enugu became one of the few cities in [[West Africa]] created out of contact with Europeans. By 1916 parts of Enugu reserved for Europeans were set up by the colonial government. The area now known as the Government Reserved Area (GRA) became the European Quarters located north of the Ogbete River; alongside this was a section developed for African residents located south of the river. The built-up area of Enugu comprised these two areas, and by 1917 the city officially gained township status. On the African side of the city a rapid influx of migrant workers sparked the development of squatter camps on the Udi Hills near the coal mines and the Iva Valley. In 1938 Enugu became the administrative capital of the [[Eastern Region, Nigeria|Eastern Region]]. The number of employed coal miners in Enugu grew from 6,000 (of mostly [[Udi, Enugu|Udi]] men) in 1948 to 8,000 in 1958. Enugu's population rose sharply with its industrialisation; the population of the city reached 62,000 in 1952. Mining in Enugu was sometimes turbulent, as demonstrated by the events of 18 November 1949 when 21 striking miners were shot and killed and 51 wounded by police under British governance. The massacre that came to be known as "The Iva Valley Shooting"{{cite book|title=Towards a comparative history of coalfield societies Studies in labour history |first1=Stefan |last1=Berger |first2=Andy |last2=Croll |first3=Norman |last3=Laporte |page=142 |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd |year=2005 |isbn=0-7546-3777-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hm95KBSc-kwC&pg=PA142}} fuelled nationalist or "Zikist" sentiments among most Nigerians, and especially amongst Eastern Nigerians.Coleman, pp. 296—302. "Zikisim" was a post [[World War II]] movement that was created out of admiration for [[Nnamdi Azikiwe]] who was a prominent nationalist of the [[National Council of Nigeria and the Cameroons]] (NCNC). The shooting was right after a period of unrest when miners were angered by the belief that their full pay was being held back by the colliery management, a belief that was pushed by the nationalist press. Many of the Zikists tried to use the Iva Valley shooting to fuel their nationalistic agenda and push the British imperial administration, out of Nigeria. ===Independence, war, and after=== {{Further|Decolonization of Africa|Nigerian Civil War}} Enugu became a municipality in 1956 with [[Umaru Altine]] its first mayor. After four years passed, Nigeria gained its independence in 1960. On 27 May 1967 the Nigerian government divided the [[Western Region, Nigeria|Western]], [[Northern Nigeria|Northern]] and Eastern Region into 12 states{{cite book |title=Civil wars of the world: major conflicts since World War II, Volume 2 |first1=Karl R. |last1=DeRouen |first2=Uk |last2=Heo |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2007 |isbn=1-85109-919-0 |page=582 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nrN077AEgzMC&pg=PA582 |location=May 27, 1967}} and Enugu was made the capital of the new East Central State. On 30 May 1967 Enugu was declared the capital of the short-lived [[Republic of Biafra]], the latter created out of the eastern Nigerian states of [[East Central State|East Central]], [[Cross River State|Cross River]] and [[Rivers State|Rivers]].{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of African history, Volume 1 Encyclopedia of African History |first=Kevin |last=Shillington |publisher=CRC Press |year=2005 |isbn=1-57958-453-5 |page=1115}}{{cite book|title=African Studies in Geography from Below |first1=Michel Ben |last1=Arrous |first2=Lazare |last2=Ki-Zerbo |publisher=African Books Collective |page=98 |year=2009 |isbn=2-86978-231-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4PQK68LNtjcC&pg=PA98}} Biafra was declared by Ojukwu because of Eastern Nigeria after their members were attacked injured and killed in a series of ethnic attacks launched by some other ethnic groups in other parts of the country following the first military coup executed by mostly Igbo generals, in which top northern Nigerian leaders among others were terminated. The main rivals of the mostly Igbo Eastern Nigerians were the [[Hausa people|Hausa]]/[[Fula people|Fulani]] people of Northern Nigeria.{{cite book|title=Ethics and nostalgia in the contemporary novel |first=John J. |last=Su |page=146 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2005 |isbn=0-521-85440-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=63m5qv0qlgMC&pg=PA146}} A northern headed war on the secession (1967—1970) and continuous attacks on the Igbos in other part of Nigeria lead Igbos from northern and western Nigeria to return to their "native" areas in eastern Nigeria and Enugu became a destination. [[Radio Biafra]], alternatively the Voice of Biafra (formerly the Eastern Nigerian Broadcasting Service), was based in Enugu;{{cite book|title=Broadcasting on the Short Waves, 1945 to Today |first=Jerome S. |last=Berg |publisher=McFarland |page=177 |year=2008 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ux9fZj6izuEC&pg=PA177 |isbn=0-7864-3674-3}} it was from here that the Biafran leader, [[Chukwuemeka Odumegwu Ojukwu]], broadcast speeches and propaganda to Biafrans and Nigeria.{{cite news|title=Biafran leader looks back |first=Barnaby |last=Phillips |date=January 29, 2000 |publisher=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/622398.stm |accessdate=2010-06-13}}{{cite journal|title=Nigeria: Drums of Defeat |date=October 6, 1967 |publisher=Time Inc. |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,844010,00.html |accessdate=2010-06-13}} Because of the war, Enugu witnessed a decrease in the number of non-Igbo, specifically non-eastern Nigerian residents. On 4 October 1967 the Nigerian military bombarded Enugu with artillery just outside its boundaries before capturing it a week later, shortly after this [[Umuahia]] became the new capital of the republic.{{cite book |title=Frontiersmen: warfare in Africa since 1950 |first=Anthony |last=Clayton |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=1999 |isbn=1-85728-525-5 |page=94 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zg5hipdurBkC&pg=PA94}} Years after the Republic of Biafra reverted to Nigeria, Enugu is still regarded as the "Capital of Igboland."{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of the Stateless Nations: S-Z |first=James |last=Minahan |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2002 |isbn=0-313-32384-4 |page=762 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K94wQ9MF2JsC&pg=PA762}} Enugu resumed in 1970 as the capital of the East Central State after the republic was dissolved. On 3 February 1976 the East Central State was made into two new states, [[Imo State|Imo]] and [[Anambra State|Anambra]]; there were then 19 states in Nigeria;{{cite book |title=Crippled giant: Nigeria since independence |first=Eghosa E. |last=Osaghae |publisher=C. Hurst & Co. Publishers |year=1998 |isbn=1-85065-350-X |page=85 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2qc7DWCzHlMC&pg=PA85}} Enugu was the capital of Anambra. On 27 August 1991 the military dictatorship of [[Ibrahim Babangida]] divided the old Anambra State into two new states, Enugu State and Anambra State.{{cite journal|title=African Studies Review |first=H. |last=Alapiki |publisher=African Studies Association |pages=49–65 |issue=3 |volume=48 |date=December 2005 |doi=10.1353/arw.2006.0003 |journal=African Studies Review}} Enugu remained as the capital of the newly created Enugu State, while [[Awka]] became the capital of the new Anambra State.{{cite book|title=The Commonwealth Yearbook 2006 |first=Richard |last=Green |page=54 |publisher=Nexus Strategic Partnerships Ltd |year=2006 |isbn=0-9549629-4-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PsALI1fatKIC&pg=PA54}} ==Geography== {{Further|Geography of Nigeria}} ===Topography=== [[File:Enugu satellite map.jpg|thumb|alt=A satellite image of Enugu and other towns that surround it with rivers and hills visible|Satellite image of Enugu and other communities neighbouring it. The Enugu escarpment can be seen on the left where it has a lighter colour; the Nyaba River can be seen on the bottom.]] Despite its name meaning ''hill top'' in the Igbo language, Enugu lies at the foot of an [[escarpment]] and not a hill. Enugu is located in the [[Cross River (Nigeria)|Cross River]] basinUdo, p. 89. and the [[Benue trough]] and has the best developed coal in this area.{{cite book|title=Geology and mineral resources of West Africa |first=J. B. |last=Wright |page=116 |publisher=Springer |year=1985 |isbn=0-04-556001-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YBDbdZrHosMC&pg=PA116 |location=Coal}} [[Precambrian]] basement rock in this region is overlaid with sediments bearing coal from the [[Cretaceous]] and [[Tertiary]] age.{{cite book|title=Coal geology |first=Larry |last=Thomas |page=64 |edition=reprint |publisher=John Wiley and Sons |year=2002 |isbn=0-471-48531-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4oYWx90ybY8C&pg=PA64 |location=Nigeria}} Coal seams in the Enugu coal district measure between {{convert|1|and|2|m|ft}} in thickness and the reserves have been estimated to be more than 300 million tonnes. Enugu's hills at the extreme may reach an elevation of {{convert|1000|m|ft}}. Highlands surrounding Enugu for the most part are underlain by sandstone, while lowlands are underlain by [[shale]]. Much of the escarpment stretching from Enugu to [[Orlu, Nigeria|Orlu]] has been ravaged by soil and gully erosion. Other geological features in Enugu include the [[Nike Lake]] near which the Nike Lake Hotel has been built. The seven story building contains 100 rooms and is located in the Independence Layout. Hotel Presidential cost [[United States Dollars|$]]2.5 million to build and was commissioned by the government of what was then the Eastern Region to serve visiting businessmen, officials and tourists.{{Cite journal|title=The African Scene |journal=Black World/Negro Digest |page=32 |date=October 1963 |volume=12 |issue=12 |publisher=Johnson Publishing Company |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZToDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA32}} In the middle of Enugu is the Michael Okpara Square, dedicated to the premier of the former Eastern Region [[Michael Okpara]]. Beside the square is located the Enugu State Government House, Enugu State House of Assembly and Enugu State Judiciary Complex.{{cite news|title=When Okpara Square turns to gymnasium |first=Adelani |last=Adepegba |date=2008-02-05 |publisher=''[[The Punch]]'' |url=http://www.punchng.com/Articl.aspx?theartic=Art2008050210401853 |accessdate=2010-10-18}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}} {{Clear}} {{Panorama | image = File:4 Enugu streets.jpg |alt = An image of four streets in Enugu juxtaposed together. | fullwidth = 4400 | fullheight = 700 | caption = Four Enugu streets | height = 150 }} Enugu's coal mines are dotted around on the outskirts of the city, a majority of which are closed. The Colliery Camp mines are located in the Iva Valley which is near the neighbouring town of [[Ngwo]] and Hilltop of Enugu. The Iva Valley coal mine is accessed through the Iva Valley road linking Enugu with Ngwo.{{cite journal|title=The Iva Faults |page=53 |journal=Bulletin |issue=6 |publisher=Geological Survey of Nigeria |year=1924}} Other coal mines are located in the Ogbete and Coal Camp layouts; these mines are located on the periphery of the city near the Iva Valley as well. Architectural design in Enugu's early years was in the hands of the British colonial administration; Enugu's architecture was consequently very European. English cottage housing and [[Victorian architecture|Victorian houses]] were used for housing Europeans and Nigerian colonial civil servants in the early 20th century until Europeans started trying to adapt their architecture to the tropical climate.{{cite book|title=African architecture: evolution and transformation |first=Nnamdi |last=Elleh |publisher=McGraw-Hill |page=331 |year=1997 |isbn=0-07-021506-5}} Some other examples of these European styles are visible in churches of the colonial era, such as the Holy Ghost Cathedral with its [[Greco-Roman world|Greco-Roman]] stained glass windows depicting Europeans. Enugu's roads were reflective of its British rule; much of the city's narrow roads in the GRA have been preserved dating back to the incorporation of the city itself.{{cite web |title=Enugu |publisher=[[FIFA]] |url=https://www.fifa.com/u17worldcup/destination/cities/city=10116/index.html |accessdate=2010-06-15}} Low rent one bedroom flats in Enugu and other Nigerian cities are known as "[[face-me-I-face-you]]" for the way a group of flats face each other and form a square where a compound entrance is led into.{{cite book|title=Newswatch |volume=14 |issue=1–14 |page=10 |publisher=Newswatch Communications Ltd |year=1991}}{{cite book|title=Prison stories: a collection of short storie[s] |first=Helon |last=Habila |page=65 |publisher=Epik Books |year=2000 |isbn=978-30397-2-5}} ==Government== {{Details|Politics of Nigeria}} Enugu city covers three [[Local Government Areas of Nigeria|local government areas]]: [[Enugu East]], [[Enugu North]] and [[Enugu South]].{{cite book|title=The Impact of Large Landowners on Land Markets |first=Raphael |last=Bostic |page=46 |publisher=Lincoln Institute of Land Policy, 2009 |isbn=1-55844-189-1}} A Local Government Council exists for each of these seats that manages sectors including primary education and health; an elected Executive Chairman and a group of elected Councillors form the Local Government Council that heads each Local Government Area.{{cite journal|title=Informal Land Delivery Processes and Access to Land for the Poor in Enugu, Nigeria |first1=U.|last1=Ikejiofor |first2=K. C. |last2=Nwogu |first3=C. O. |last3=Nwanunobi |year=2004 |publisher=University of Birmingham |isbn=0-7044-2243-3}}{{Cite journal|title=Nigeria |journal=[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]] |date=February 1982 |page=67 |volume=37 |issue=4 |publisher=Johnson Publishing Company |issn=0012-9011 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=deYZsW0DlSIC&pg=PA67}} Enugu South is split between its rural and urban parts when electing an Executive Chairman. The Executive Chairmen include Paul Ogbe for Enugu South Urban, Theresa Egbo for Enugu South Rural, Emeka Nnamani for Enugu North, and Christopher Ugwu for Enugu East; these chairmen represent their LGA's in the Enugu State House of Assembly.{{cite web|url=http://www.enugustate.gov.ng/legislative.php |title=Members of the Enugu State House of Assembly |publisher=Enugu State Government |accessdate=2010-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819043751/http://www.enugustate.gov.ng/legislative.php |archivedate=2010-08-19 |df= }} The Ministry of Lands, Survey and Town Planning (at the state level) and the Local Planning Authority (at the local government level) are responsible for the administration of urban lands and town planning. Government House, Enugu is where the government of the state is based. |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKL0674057420070206 |accessdate=2010-06-11}} The population of Enugu is predominantly Christian,{{cite book|title=Freedom is more than a word: towards a theology of empowerment |first1=Obiora F. |last1=Ike |page=259 |publisher=Catholic Institute for Development Justice and Peace (CIDJAP) |year=1998 |isbn=978-34677-0-0}} as is the rest of southeastern Nigeria.{{cite book|title=Voyages in World History, Volume 2 |first1=Valerie |last1=Hansen |first2=Kenneth |last2=Curtis |page=833 |publisher=Cengage Learning |year=2008 |isbn=0-618-07725-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=klcYZE-jE74C&pg=PA833}} Like the rest of Nigeria most people in Enugu speak [[Nigerian English]] alongside the dominant language in the region.{{cite book|title=The Report: Nigeria 2010 |publisher=Oxford Business Group |page=14 |year=2010 |isbn=1-907065-14-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VFONkYzHco8C&pg=PA14}} In this case the dominant language is [[Igbo language|Igbo]].{{cite book|title=Concise Encyclopaedia of World History |first=Carlos |last=Ramirez-Faria |publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors |page=519 |location=Nigeria |year=2007 |isbn=81-269-0775-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGKsS-9h4BYC&pg=PT529}} Nigerian English, or ''pidgin'' (a mix of English and indigenous words) is often used because of ethnic diversity and sometimes because of the diversity of dialects in the Igbo language.{{cite book|title=Negotiating power and privilege: Igbo career women in contemporary Nigeria |first=Philomina Ezeagbor |last=Okeke-Ihejirika |publisher=Ohio University Press |year=2004 |page=26 |isbn=0-89680-241-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dqr2EmM0m7cC&pg=PA26}} In cultural and linguistic terms Enugu is within the Northern cluster of the Igbo region which includes other towns and cities like [[Awka]] and [[Nsukka]].{{cite book|title=Christianity and Ibo culture |first=Edmund |last=Ilogu |publisher=Brill Archive |year=1974 |page=2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0uMUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA2 |isbn=90-04-04021-8}} The indigenous people of Enugu include the Ogui Nike who live in the areas surrounding Hotel Presidential, Obiagu, Ama-Igbo, Ihewuzi and Onu-Asata. Other groups include the Awkunanaw people, who live mainly in the Achara Layout and Uwani areas. The Enugwu Ngwo people live in Hilltop on the west of the city with their farm lands sprawling all over the valley. Other Nike people live around the Abakpa, Iji-Nike, and Emene areas of the city.{{cite book|title=Ibo village communities |author=J. W. Lieber |publisher=Institute of Education, [[University of Ibadan]] |year=1971 |pages=65–71}}{{cite journal|title=Nigeria magazine |first=Edward Harland |last=Duckworth |issue=68–71 |pages=241–242 |publisher=Cultural Division of the Federal Ministry of Information, Nigeria |year=1961}}{{cite book|title=Nike chieftaincy, 1919–1985 |first=Jude Onuchukwu |last=Nnamani |publisher=Enugu Government Printer}} Most of the non-indigenous people of Enugu are migrants from other parts of the [[Igboland|Igbo cultural area]]. After the majority Igbo, the [[Yoruba people]] are another significant ethnic group found present in Enugu; other groups include the [[Hausa people|Hausa]], [[Kanuri people|Kanuri]], [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]], and [[Fula people|Fulani people]].{{cite journal|title=Explaining Inter-Ethnic Coexistence and Harmony in Enugu city, Southeastern Nigeria |first=Akachi Cornelius |last=Odoemene |publisher=University of Ibadan |pages=9–13 |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:1alpOUdSuSAJ:iussp2009.princeton.edu/download.aspx%3FsubmissionId%3D90623+Explaining+Inter-Ethnic+Coexistence+and+Harmony+in+Enugu+city,+Southeastern+Nigeria&hl=en&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgfS7i6J5YxEHceZG9ZdYv4g-HjZ0RCwIB9FM-Vpduh8FvNUlYWg1i3wI35yKyQMX7UIMcLfOqdeP4VfHoq4mAbwHgRo-R3cI2sVQ_QQOggYXkYwXEExnHv_mizVboLDEc03SFo&sig=AHIEtbTZa9w6FJWeoGADzwaG2fxd2m4y9g}} ===Crime=== Enugu's crime rate rose in 2009 as kidnapping and armed robbery rates increased in southeastern Nigeria specifically between September and December.{{cite news|title=Police arrest 1,088 in Enugu |first=Tony |last=Edike |publisher=''Vanguard'' |date=February 25, 2010 |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201002250577.html |accessdate=2010-06-26}} The Enugu State government sought to check the high kidnapping rates by passing a bill on February 2009 that made kidnapping by the use of a weapon a [[Capital punishment|capital offence]]; the bill was passed by the Enugu House of Assembly unanimously.{{cite news|title=Enugu Assembly’s Law On Kidnapping |first=Emmanuel |last=Nzomiwu |date=January 14, 2010 |publisher=''Daily Independent'' |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201001150515.html |accessdate=2010-06-26}} 1,088 arrests were made in the city between September and December 2009; 270 of these were in September, 303 were in October, 295 in November and 220 were in December. 477 of these detainees were accused of committing capital offences which included kidnapping. The motives of kidnappers in Enugu are primarily financial and some ransoms went into the millions of [[Nigerian naira|Naira]]. The Chief Press Secretary to the Governor of Enugu State, Dan Nwomeh, had his ransom set as high as ₦500 million (3.3 million [[United States dollar|US Dollars]] {{As of|2010|June|26}}),{{cite web|url=http://www.xe.com/ucc/convert.cgi?Amount=500000000&From=NGN&To=USD |title=Nigeria Nairas (NGN) to United States Dollars (USD) rate |publisher=[[XE.com]] |date=June 26, 2010 |accessdate=2010-06-26}} dropping to ₦200 million and then ₦50 million before he was released without a ransom being paid because of the refusal of the government to negotiate with the kidnappers. Much of the crime in Enugu and the rest of Nigeria has been attributed to unemployment.{{cite news|title=South-East under siege: Robbers, kidnappers on the rampage |date=July 25, 2009 |first1=Tony |last1=Edike |first2=Anayo |last2=Okoli |first3=Chidi |last3=Nkwopara |first4=Vincent |last4=Ujumadu |publisher=''Vanguard'' |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200907271060.html |accessdate=2010-06-26}} ==Culture== {{See also|Culture of Nigeria|Igbo culture}} {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://news.bbc.co.uk/media/images/45857000/jpg/_45857165_masq_masqs_766.jpg Enugu's Mmanwu masquerades in full costume]{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_pictures/8078727.stm |title=In pictures: Nigeria's colourful masquerades |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2010-06-27 | date=June 3, 2009}} }} As a Northern Igbo city, Enugu shares cultural traits with its neighbouring towns. Two important Igbo traditional festivals take place in Enugu annually; the [[Mmanwu]] festival and the [[New Yam Festival of the Igbo|New yam festival]]. The Mmanwu festival takes place in November and features various types of masquerades that each have a name. This festival is held at the [[Nnamdi Azikiwe Stadium]] as a parade of carnival-like masquerades that are accompanied by music and it is supported by the Enugu Council of Arts and Culture.{{cite web|title=Tourism |publisher=Enugu State Government |url=http://www.enugustate.gov.ng/tourism.php |accessdate=2010-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918234250/http://www.enugustate.gov.ng/tourism.php |archivedate=2010-09-18 |df= }}{{cite book|title=Third Enugu State Mmanwu Festival and Iri-Ji Tradition |first=Meki |last=Nzewi |page=6 |publisher=Enugu State (Nigeria). Ministry of Information |year=1994}}{{Cite journal|title=Spirits Incarnate: Cultural Revitalisation in a Nigerian Masquerade Festival |first=Bess |last=Reed |journal=African Arts |pages=50–59 |issue=38 |volume=1 |publisher=James S. Coleman African Studies Center, University of California |year=2005 |url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-4653752/Spirits-incarnate-cultural-revitalization-in.html}} The second important Igbo festival, the New yam festival known as 'iwa ji', is held between August and October marking the harvesting and feasting of the new yam. The yam is a root vegetable that is the staple crop and a cultural symbol for the Igbo people. Recently created festivals include the Enugu Festival of Arts which is managed by the Enugu Council of Arts and Culture. The festival highlights African culture and traditions and it is here that the Enugu Council of Arts and Culture included the Mmanwu parade as part of the events. The Enugu Festival of Arts was started in 1986; it has modernised the Mmanwu festival by transferring it from its traditional village surroundings to the urban setting of Enugu. [[Diana, Princess of Wales]] was a notable spectator of Enugu's cultural shows when she visited the city in 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/73389832/Hulton-Archive |title=Diana in Enugu |publisher=[[Getty Images]] |accessdate=2010-06-27}} The tourism industry in Enugu, managed by the Enugu State Tourism Board (ESTB), is small; however, the state government recognises a variety of historic and recreational sites. These sites include places like the Udi Hills, from which the majority of Enugu city can be viewed. The Polo amusement park is a [[funfair]] that is among the first generation of public parks in the city;{{cite journal|title=Administrative and legal frameworks for promoting landscape architecture: a third world contribution |first=J. B. |last=Falade |publisher=Routledge |year=1989}} other parks in the city include the Murtala Muhammed Park.Hudgens, p. 1072. Enugu's former coal mines, Onyeama and Okpara, are open to public visits. Some other spots include: The Institute of Management and Technology (IMT) Sculptural Garden and Art Gallery, the Eastern Region Parliamentary Building, the Old Government Lodge, and Enugu Golf course. Enugu Zoo is another attraction in the city. It is divided into the botanical garden and the zoological section.{{cite book|title=Nigeria, a People United, a Future Assured: Survey of states |first1=A.b. |last1=Mamman |first2=J.o. |last2=Oyebanji |first3=S.w. |last3=Petters |publisher=Federal Ministry of Information |page=196 |year=2000 |isbn=978-010-432-1}} A National Museum is located near Enugu at its north, although it receives few visitors. It is managed by National Commission for Museums and Monuments (NCMM). Other galleries include the Bona Gallery.{{cite news|title=Enugu: Hill top of many splendours |first=Maurice |last=Archibong |date=June 29, 2006 |newspaper=''The Daily Sun'' |publisher=Sun News |url=http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/travels/2006/june/29/travels-29-06-2006-001.htm |accessdate=2010-10-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060827143417/http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/travels/2006/june/29/travels-29-06-2006-001.htm |archivedate=August 27, 2006 }} ==Entertainment== ===Music=== {{Further|Music of Nigeria}} [[File:Flavour N'abania.jpg|thumb|alt=Image of musician Flavour|[[Flavour N'abania]] at the [[2014 Africa Magic Viewers Choice Awards]]]] Enugu rose as an important centre for [[Highlife music]] in Nigeria in the 1950s. The Igbo dominated version of the genre grew out of earlier "Igbo [[blues]]" or "[[Palm-wine music|palm wine music]]" and further spread in popularity to the [[Southern Cameroons]] where Enugu had considerable influence in arts and culture in towns such as [[Limbe, Cameroon|Limbe]], [[Tiko]] and [[Douala]].{{cite book|title=Culture and customs of Cameroon |first=John Mukum |last=Mbaku |page=200 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2005 |isbn=0-313-33231-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LJbTfGbk-LEC&pg=PA200}} Some prominent musicians with origins in Enugu include [[Sonny Okosun]], an [[afrobeat]] musician who was born and raised in Enugu and joined his first band The Postmen that was based in the city in 1965;{{cite book|title=Highlife Music in West Africa |first=Sonny |last=Oti |page=28 |publisher=African Books Collective |year=2009 |isbn=978-8422-08-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ysJlY9Z9uAC&pg=PA28}}{{cite book|title=Historical trends of Nigerian indigenous and contemporary music |first=S. J. |last=Timothy-Asobele |page=25 |publisher=Rothmed International |year=2002}} Celestine Ukwu joined Michael Ejeagha's Enugu based Paradise Rhythm Orchestra in 1962 before creating his own band{{cite book|title=Musicmakers of West Africa |first=John |last=Collins |page=51 |publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers |year=1985 |isbn=0-89410-075-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yIHfybGz5HoC&pg=PA51}} and had a recreational club in the city after the Nigeria Civil War;, Harry Mosco Agada of the "I'm a country boy" fame.{{cite book|title=Highlife Music in West Africa |first=Sonny |last=Oti |page=163 |publisher=African Books Collective |year=2009 |isbn=978-8422-08-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ysJlY9Z9uAC&pg=PA163}} other musicians include [[2Face Idibia]]; a [[Nigerian hip hop|Hip hop]]/[[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] musician who partly grew up and studied music in the city.{{cite journal|title=Focus on Africa: BBC magazine |publisher=BBC African Service |page=50 |volume=16–17 |first=Peter |last=Okwoche |year=2005}} Other notable musicians originating from Enugu include [[Igbo rap|rapper]] [[Phyno]], Slowdog, [[William Onyeabor]], and highlife musician [[Flavour N'abania]]. ===Media and literature=== {{See also|Media of Nigeria|Nigerian literature}} English-language newspapers published and sold in Enugu include the ''Daily Star'', ''Evening Star'', ''The Renaissance'' and ''New Renaissance''.{{cite book|title=Post-imperial English: status change in former British and American colonies, 1940–1990 |first1=Joshua A. |last1=Fishman |first2=Andrew W. |last2=Conrad |first3=Alma |last3=Rubal-Lopez |publisher=Walter de Gruyter |pages=71–72 |year=1996 |isbn=3-11-014754-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SIu244rlVu8C&pg=PA71}} One of the earliest newspapers published in Enugu was the ''Eastern Sentinel'' published by Nnamdi Azikiwe's Zik Group in 1955, but failed in 1960.{{cite book|title=Main currents in Nigerian education thought |first=Anthony Assam Owan |last=Enoh |publisher=Midland Press |page=32 |year=1996 |isbn=}}{{cite book|title=Press freedom and communication in Africa |first1=Festus |last1=Eribo |first2=William |last2=Jong-Ebot |page=60 |publisher=Africa World Press |year=1997 |isbn=0-86543-551-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aMM2qKU9bVUC&pg=PA60}} Among the city's television and radio stations are the [[Nigerian Television Authority]]'s network affiliate (NTA Enugu) headquarters located at Independence Layout; and the [[Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria]] (FRCN) network affiliate station (Radio Enugu) which broadcasts in English, Igbo, [[Ibibio language|Efik]], [[Ijo languages|Ijaw]] and [[Tiv language|Tiv]].{{cite book |title=Africa South of the Sahara 2003 |author=Eur |publisher=Routledge |page=804 |year=2003 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1KBP7QbalX0C&pg=PA804 |isbn=1-85743-131-6}} Enugu State Broadcasting Service Television (ESBS-TV) is a state owned television broadcasting company which offers 18 hours of continuous broadcasting on weekends.{{cite book|title=Global entertainment media: content, audiences, issues LEA's communication series |first=Anne |last=Cooper-Chen |publisher=Routledge |page=106 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gb8Bkmq5254C&pg=PA106 |year=2005 |isbn=0-8058-5169-0}} Enugu, after [[Lagos]] is the preferred city for shooting [[Cinema of Nigeria|films in Nigeria]] and a film production centre in the East.{{cite journal|title=Nollywood Confidential: The unlikely rise of Nigerian video film |first=John C. |last=McCall |pages=98–109 |journal=[[Transition Magazine]] |publisher=Indiana University Press |volume=13 |issue=95 |year=2004}}{{cite journal|title=Nollywood in Lagos, Lagos in Nollywood Films |first=Jonathan |last=Haynes |pages=131–150 |journal=[[Africa Today]] |publisher=Indiana University Press |volume=54 |issue=2 |year=2007 |doi=10.2979/aft.2007.54.2.130}} In 2007, Enugu hosted the first-ever film festival in the state, the Enugu International Film Festival. Held at Hotel Presidential, the festival's intent was to highlight Enugu as a "film making hub" in Africa including movie premiers and prizes for different film categories.{{cite news|title=Movie stars seek new direction for Nollywood |first=Azuh |last=Amatus |date=December 28, 2007 |newspaper=''The Daily Sun'' |publisher=Sun News |url=http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/showtime/2007/dec/28/showtime-28-12-2007-002.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420235433/http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/showtime/2007/dec/28/showtime-28-12-2007-002.htm |archivedate=April 20, 2009 |df= }} Some of Nigeria's well-known writers were born and have lived in the city of Enugu. [[Chinua Achebe]], writer of [[Things Fall Apart]] lived in Enugu in 1958, the year the book was published.Ezenwa-Ohaeto, pp. 67–68. He again moved to the city during the Nigerian Civil War after escaping [[Lagos]] with his family. It was at this time that he met and became friends with Nigerian poet [[Christopher Okigbo#War and legacy|Christopher Okigbo]] where they started the publishing house [[Citadel Press]], among its titles ''How the Dog was Domesticated'' and ''How the Leopard Got His Claws''.Ezenwa-Ohaeto, p. 125. Okigbo lived in Enugu during the early months of the Nigerian Civil War. His home in [[Hilltop, Nigeria|Hilltop]] contained many of his unpublished writings which were mostly destroyed by bombing early in the war.{{cite news|title=Chris Okigbo, 42 years after |first=Onukwube |last=Ofoelue |date=August 16, 2009 |location=War and legacy |newspaper=''The Daily Sun'' |publisher=Sun News
